choices.text: Deficiency in Bruton's tyrosine kinase (BTK)
Deficiency in the common gamma chain of cytokine receptors
Deficiency in NADPH oxidase

questions.text: In a pediatric immunology case discussion, a child with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections and the development of granulomas is presented. These clinical features are indicative of a specific underlying genetic defect. Which of the following genetic deficiencies is most commonly associated with this type of clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Deficiency in NADPH oxidase

 

Option C:

 

The child’s clinical presentation of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections combined with granuloma formation is characteristic of Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD), which is most commonly due to a deficiency in NADPH oxidase. This enzyme complex is crucial for the respiratory burst in phagocytes, essential for killing ingested pathogens. A defect in this enzyme leads to an inability to produce reactive oxygen species necessary for microbial killing, resulting in the clinical features observed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deficiency in Bruton's tyrosine kinase (BTK): This defect leads to X-linked agammaglobulinemia, primarily presenting with recurrent bacterial infections due to a lack of mature B cells and immunoglobulins but not typically fungal infections or granulomas.

 

Option B. Deficiency in the common gamma chain of cytokine receptors: This mutation results in X-linked severe combined immunodeficiency (X-SCID), characterized by a profound deficiency in both T and B cells, leading to severe viral, bacterial, and fungal infections but not specifically granulomas.

 

Option D. Deficiency in adenosine deaminase (ADA): This enzyme deficiency results in ADA-SCID, another form of severe combined immunodeficiency, characterized by severe recurrent infections from a variety of pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi, and some immune dysregulation, but granulomas are less commonly reported than in CGD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Regarding respiratory burst:

 

  • During phagocytosis NADPH oxidase leads to the production of superoxide
  • Genetic deficiency of NADPH oxidase causes chronic granulomatous disease
  • Raid consumption of the oxygen
  • Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to absence of NADPH oxidase in macrophages and neutrophils  →  Ingestion of bacteria normally by macrophages but cannot destroy them.
  • But streptococci and pneumococci themselves produce H2O2 and are destroyed by the myeloperoxidase system of the macrophages.
  • Staphylococci being catalase positive can detoxify H2O2 in the macrophages and are not destroyed in such persons →   recurrent pyogenic infection by staphylococci, which is common in chronic granulomatous disease.                                                                                     

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 474.

choices.text: It converts hemoglobin to methaemoglobin
It is a cofactor of various enzymes

questions.text: A 24-year-old researcher is studying the antioxidant defense mechanisms in the human body and is particularly interested in the role of glutathione. While reviewing the literature, he encounters various functions and characteristics of glutathione but finds conflicting information regarding one of its roles. Based on your knowledge, which of the following statements about glutathione (GSH) is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  It converts hemoglobin to methaemoglobin

 

Option B:

 

  • Gamma glutamyl cysteinyl glycine (Tripeptide : -SH group of cysteine is active part / reducing agent of GSH) reduction of methemoglobin (fe 3+) to normal Hb (fe2+)

 

Functions:

 

  • Detoxification of organophosphorus compounds, halogenated compounds, nitrogenous substances (dinitro chloro benzene), heavy metals and drug metabolism.
  • Meister’s cycle / Gamma glutamyl cycle: Transport of A. As across cell membrane, Absorption of neutral A. As in intestine , renal tubules & Brain
  • Free radical Scavenging:  Maintains RBC – membrane integrity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. True, as glutathione is composed of three amino acids: glutamate, cysteine, and glycine.

 

Option C. True, glutathione plays a significant role in the detoxification process by conjugating with various xenobiotics, aiding in their excretion from the body.

 

Option D. True, glutathione acts as a cofactor for glutathione peroxidase and other enzymes involved in the reduction of peroxides and maintenance of redox status within cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glutathione does not convert haemoglobin to methaemoglobin. Methaemoglobin formation occurs when the iron in hemoglobin is oxidized from the ferrous (Fe2+) to the ferric (Fe3+) state, which can happen through various mechanisms, but not directly due to glutathione. In fact, glutathione plays a role in reducing oxidative stress in cells and can help to protect against the oxidation of hemoglobin.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 272-273.

questions.text: In a clinical seminar focused on oxidative stress and cellular antioxidants, a biochemistry professor discusses the biochemical properties that enable glutathione to act as a potent antioxidant. One medical student asks about the specific functional group in glutathione that is primarily responsible for its antioxidant activity. Which of the following is the correct answer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  Sulfhydryl

 

Option B:

 

  • The antioxidant activity of glutathione is dependent on maintenance of its reduced state.
  • The enzyme glutathione reductase transfers electrons from NADPH via FAD to oxidized glutathione, which is composed of two glutathione molecules held together by a disulfide bridge.
  • Reduced glutathione is a tripeptide with a free sulfhydryl group, which is important to the antioxidant activity of glutathione.

 

 

  • In red blood cells, the function of cysteine residues of hemoglobin and other proteins is maintained by the reducing power of glutathione.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hydroxyl: Incorrect, as the hydroxyl group is not the primary reactive group in glutathione involved in antioxidant activity.

 

Option C. Carboxyl: Incorrect, the carboxyl group is a common functional group in many biomolecules but not the key reactive group in glutathione for its antioxidant function.

 

Option D. Guanidino: Incorrect, the guanidino group is found in arginine and is not involved in the antioxidant activity of glutathione.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sulfhydryl (-SH) group in glutathione is crucial for its role as an antioxidant. This group, found in the cysteine residue of glutathione, is highly reactive and can donate a hydrogen atom to neutralize free radicals, making it essential for reducing oxidative stress in cells.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 133,212,217,218.

questions.text: During a workshop on nutritional supplements and their therapeutic uses, a health coach discusses the benefits of N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) in supporting the body's antioxidant systems. One attendee, a fitness enthusiast who's keen on optimizing her recovery times and overall health through nutrition, inquires about the specific compound that NAC helps to replenish in the body, enhancing its antioxidant defenses. What should the health coach respond?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Glutathione

 

Option A:

 

  • The active part of both Glutathione and N-acetyl cysteine is the Sulfhydryl group of Cysteine. So, N-Acetyl Cysteine replenishes Glutathione.
  • N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) is a glutathione precursor, and it protects NO˙ from being metabolized by free radical scavengers. Hence enhances NO˙ activity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Glycine: Incorrect, as NAC directly influences glutathione levels rather than glycine.

 

Option C. Glutamate: Incorrect, glutamate is a neurotransmitter and not the primary compound replenished by NAC.

 

Option D. GABA: Incorrect, GABA (Gamma-Aminobutyric Acid) is also a neurotransmitter and not directly affected by NAC supplementation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) is a precursor to glutathione, one of the body's most powerful antioxidants. By replenishing intracellular levels of glutathione, NAC supports the body's ability to neutralize free radicals and reduce oxidative stress, which is particularly beneficial for athletes and those engaged in regular intense physical activity.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 228.

questions.text: In a clinical case discussion focusing on a patient with a complex presentation of recurrent infections involving multiple organ systems, alongside excessive inflammation with granulomas, gingivitis, aphthous ulcers, and seborrheic dermatitis, the team is considering an underlying enzymatic deficiency as the cause. Given the patient's symptoms and history, which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NADPH oxidase

 

Option B:

 

  • It is a case of chronic granulomatous disease of childhood, caused by a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex → resulting in lack of formation of superoxide by neutrophils and other phagocytic cells.
  • So the affected individuals lacks the ability to kill invading microbes that are engulfed by these phagocytic cells
  • Key point: Patients usually present with a past medical history.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase: Deficient in McArdle disease; c/f- muscle cramps and weakness on exercise.

 

Option C. Myeloperoxidase: Present inside the phagocytes which destroys the bacteria. So, genetic deficiency of this enzyme →  recurrent infections with peroxidase positive bacteria such as Haemophilus.

 

Option D. Xanthine oxidase: During myocardial ischemia, the activity of xanthine oxidase is increased→ reperfusion injury by free radicals.

 

Educational objective:

 

NADPH oxidase deficiency is the underlying cause of Chronic Granulomatous Disease, which presents with recurrent infections, excessive inflammation, and granuloma formation due to impaired microbial killing by phagocytes.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p704-705.

questions.text: A clinical discussion is centered on diseases related to the dysregulation of reactive oxygen species. One of the residents mentions a condition characterized by a deficiency in the production of free radicals, leading to a specific disease phenotype. Which of the following diseases is the result of deficient production of free radicals?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Option C:

 

  • Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to absence of NADPH oxidase in macrophages and neutrophils  →  Ingestion of bacteria normally by macrophages but cannot destroy them.
  • But streptococci and pneumococci themselves produce H2O2 and are destroyed by the myeloperoxidase system of the macrophages.
  • Staphylococci being catalase positive can detoxify H2O2 in the macrophages and are not destroyed in such persons → recurrent pyogenic infection by staphylococci, which is common in chronic granulomatous disease.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alzheimer’s disease: This neurodegenerative disorder is associated with the accumulation of abnormal proteins in the brain, not primarily with a deficiency in the production of free radicals.

 

Option B. Cancer: While free radicals can contribute to DNA damage and cancer, cancer is not typically caused by a deficiency in free radical production.

 

Option D. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, and it is not directly related to a deficiency in free radical production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease is associated with a deficiency in the production of free radicals due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex, leading to increased susceptibility to infections and granuloma formation. Understanding the role of reactive oxygen species in immune function is important for diagnosing and managing CGD.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 474.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT typically a primary target of free radical damage?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycosaminoglycans

 

Option D:

 

  • Almost all biological macromolecules are damaged by free radicals → leads to oxidation of sulfhydryl group containing enzymes, loss of function and fragmentation of proteins.
  • Peroxidation of PUFA in plasma membranes results in loss of membrane functions and leads to formation of lipid peroxidation products like malondialdehyde in biological fluids.
  • Polysaccharides can also undergo degradation.
  • DNA is damaged by strand breaks causing inhibition of protein and enzyme synthesis directly and cell death or mutation and carcinogenesis indirectly.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. PUFA (Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids): PUFAs are major components of cell membranes and can be readily oxidized by free radicals. This lipid peroxidation can lead to cell membrane damage, disruption of cellular integrity, and inflammation, contributing to diseases such as atherosclerosis and other inflammatory conditions.

 

Option B. Protein: Proteins, including enzymes, transporters, and structural proteins, can be modified by free radicals. This can alter their structure and function, leading to a loss of activity, aggregation, or misfolding, which are implicated in various diseases including neurodegenerative disorders.

 

Option C. DNA: Free radicals can cause various types of DNA damage, including base modifications, strand breaks, and cross-linking. This damage is significant because it can lead to mutations, genomic instability, and cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Free radicals primarily target and damage essential cellular components like PUFA (found in cell membranes), proteins (including enzymes and structural proteins), and DNA, which can lead to mutations and cancer.

 

Mucopolysaccharides or glycosaminoglycans (GAG) are heteropolysaccharides which contain uronic acid and amino sugars. They are generally not affected by free radicals.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 470-475.

questions.text: A clinical immunologist is presenting a case of a patient with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) to medical residents. CGD is characterized by recurrent infections due to the inability of phagocytes to effectively destroy pathogens. The immunologist emphasizes the importance of a specific enzyme in the innate immune response, particularly in the process known as the respiratory burst, which is defective in CGD. The residents are asked to identify the enzyme responsible for this crucial step in the pathogen-killing mechanism of phagocytes. Which enzyme is deficient in patients with CGD, leading to their increased susceptibility to infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NADPH – oxidase

 

Option A:

 

  • The biochemical events accompanying phagocytosis is known as respiratory burst.
  • NADPH oxidase in the inflammatory cells such as neutrophils, eosinophils, monocytes, and macrophages produce superoxide anion by respiratory burst during phagocytosis.
  • The superoxide is converted  hydrogen peroxide   then hypochlorous acid (HClO) with the help of superoxide dismutase (SOD) and myeloperoxidase (MPO).
  • The superoxide and hypochlorous ions (free radicals) are the final effectors of bactericidal action.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Macrophages produce NO˙ from arginine by the action of nitric oxide synthase, which is an important antibacterial mechanism.

 

Option C. Mitochondria have a higher level of glutathione and glutathione.

 

Peroxidase (POD), which prevents lipid peroxidation. Thus, H2O2 is removed by POD.

 

Option D. Peroxisomes produce H2O2, which kills bacteria by neutrophils → unwanted H2O2 is then detoxified by catalase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NADPH oxidase plays a central role in the respiratory burst of phagocytes, a process critical for the body's defense against pathogens. This enzyme catalyzes the production of superoxide anions (O2-) from oxygen using NADPH as an electron donor, leading to the generation of various reactive oxygen species that are potent antimicrobial agents.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 474.

questions.text: A nutritionist is advising a patient on dietary choices to enhance antioxidant intake for overall health and well-being. The patient is curious about various vitamins and their specific health benefits, particularly in relation to antioxidant activity. The nutritionist lists several vitamins, asking the patient to identify which one is not typically associated with antioxidant functions. Which vitamin does not have a primary role as an antioxidant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholecalciferol

 

Option B:

 

Cholecalciferol, also known as vitamin D3, is not primarily known for its antioxidant action. Instead, it plays a crucial role in calcium and phosphorus homeostasis and bone health.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Retinol: Also known as vitamin A, retinol has antioxidant properties that help protect cells from the damaging effects of free radicals.

 

Option C. Ascorbate: Also known as vitamin C, ascorbate is a well-known antioxidant that helps protect cells from oxidative stress and is involved in the synthesis of collagen.

 

Option D. Tocopherol: Also known as vitamin E, tocopherol is recognized for its strong antioxidant properties, protecting cell membranes from oxidative damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antioxidants:

 

  1. Vitamin E: lipid phase antioxidant.
  2. Vitamin C: aqueous phase antioxidant. (option c)
  3. Ceruloplasmin: extracellular fluid antioxidant.
  4. Caffeine: effective antioxidant.
  5. Cysteine, glutathione, carotenoids, flavonoids and vitamin A: minor antioxidants. (option a)
  6. Beta carotene: chain-breaking antioxidant (less effective than alpha tocopherol) (option d)
  7. Food items with antioxidant activity: Spices, Curcumin, Fruits and vegetables- berries, broccoli, spinach, asparagus and green tea contain flavonoids, flavones.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 484

questions.text: A patient with a history of cardiovascular disease is being advised to increase their intake of antioxidant-rich foods to help manage their condition. Which of the following nutrients listed is NOT commonly recognized for its antioxidant activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phylloquinone

 

Option D:

 

Phylloquinone, also known as vitamin K1, is involved in blood clotting and bone metabolism but is not primarily known for its antioxidant properties.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vitamin E: Vitamin E is a well-known antioxidant that protects cell membranes from oxidative damage.

 

Option B. Vitamin C: Vitamin C, or ascorbic acid, is a potent antioxidant that scavenges free radicals and can regenerate other antioxidants within the body.

 

Option C. Carotenoids and flavonoids: These are plant-derived compounds that possess antioxidant properties, helping to protect cells from oxidative damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antioxidants:

 

  1. Vitamin E: lipid phase antioxidant.
  2. Vitamin C: aqueous phase antioxidant.
  3. Ceruloplasmin: extracellular fluid antioxidant.
  4. Caffeine: effective antioxidant.
  5. Cysteine, glutathione, carotenoids, flavonoids and vitamin A: minor antioxidants.
  6. Beta carotene: chain-breaking antioxidant (less effective than alpha tocopherol)
  7. Food items with antioxidant activity: Spices, Curcumin, Fruits and vegetables- berries, broccoli, spinach, asparagus and green tea contain flavonoids, flavone

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 476
